Submodules¶

mdma.spatial.periodic module¶

Module defining helper functions for distance calculations in periodic boundary conditions.

mdma.spatial.periodic.delta(x1, x2, box)[source]¶

Displacement between two sets of points in a d-dimensional periodic space.

Parameters

  • x1 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for first set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • x2 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for second set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • box (numpy.ndarray) – A d-dimensional array giving the box width in each dimension.

Returns

x2 - x1 but with displacements wrapped inside the box boundaries (i.e. the nearest image convention).

Return type

delta (numpy.ndarray)

mdma.spatial.periodic.distance(x1, x2, box, correct_drift=False)[source]¶

Distance between two sets of points in a d-dimensional periodic space.

This functions analagously to numpy.spatial.cdist.

Parameters

  • x1 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for first set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • x2 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for second set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • box (numpy.ndarray) – A d-dimensional array giving the box width in each dimension.

  • correct_drift (bool) – Whether to correct for drift in the centre of mass.

Returns

The n distances i.e. \(\{|\mathbf{x}_2^{(i)} - \mathbf{x}_1^{(i)}|\}_{i=1}^n\), where displacements are wrapped inside the box boundaries (i.e. the nearest image convention).

Return type

delta (numpy.ndarray)

mdma.spatial.periodic.self_intermediate_scattering_function(x1, x2, box, q=6.283185307179586)[source]¶

Self intermediate scattering function between two configurations of points.

The correlation function is defined as the Fourier transform of the self part of the van Hove function (also known as the dynamic structure factor):

\(F(t_1, t_2; \mathbf{q}) = \frac{1}{N} \Big\langle \sum_{i=1}^N \exp{(i \mathbf{q} \cdot (\mathbf{x}_i(t_1) - \mathbf{x}_i(t_2)))} \Big\rangle\)

where \(\mathbf{q}\) is the wave vector of the Fourier transform. This implementation assumes isotropy, so the exponential reduces to a sinc function and only the magnitude of the wavevector matters so \(q\) is a scalar.

Parameters

  • x1 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for first set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • x2 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for second set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • box (numpy.ndarray) – A d-dimensional array giving the box width in each dimension.

  • q (scalar) – Magnitude of the wavevector, typically taken as \(2\pi / \sigma\) where \(\sigma\) is the typical particle size.

Returns

The self-intermediate scattering function (\(F\) in the above equation).

Return type

F (scalar)

mdma.spatial.periodic.self_overlap(x1, x2, box, tol=0.3)[source]¶

Self overlap between two configurations of points.

Overlap is defined as:

\(Q(t_1, t_2) = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \Theta\Big(|\mathbf{x}_i(t_1) - \mathbf{x}_i(t_2)| - a\Big)\)

where \(\Theta(\cdots)\) is the Heaviside theta function and \(a\) is the tolerance to count the pair as overlapping.

Parameters

  • x1 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for first set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • x2 (numpy.ndarray) – An n by d array for second set of n points in a d-dimensional space.

  • box (numpy.ndarray) – A d-dimensional array giving the box width in each dimension.

  • tol (bool) – Tolerance to count an overlap (\(a\) in the above equation).

Returns

The self-overlap (\(Q\) in the above equation).

Return type

overlap (scalar)
